As of now, the WHO has reported 4,015 fatalities from the Wuhan coronavirus (COVID-19). The countries with the biggest cases of the COVID-19 are: - China: 80,924 cases
- Italy: 9,172 cases
- South Korea: 7,513 cases
- Iran: 7,161 cases
- France: 1,402 cases
- Germany: 1,139 cases
- Spain: 1,024 cases So far, the country that has suffered the most deaths from COVID-19 is China (3,140 deaths so far). As of now, the number of fatalities (i.e. deaths) from the COVID-19 in the countries listed above are: - China: 3,140 deaths
- Italy: 463 deaths
- South Korea: 54 deaths
- Iran: 237 deaths
- France: 30 deaths
- Germany: 2 deaths
- Spain: 28 deaths The biggest contributor to deaths from COVID-19 is China. China has tackled the outbreak aggressively in their country. It does not appear that the number of deaths in China is increasing for the time being. Italy has also taken drastic measures to tackle the outbreak. Cases and deaths of COVID-19 have increased in Italy within February and March. It appears that the actions that those countries have taken may have stabilized the number of cases of COVID-19 which may halt the slow the number of deaths. According to the Centers for Disease Control (CDC), the National Health Service (NHS) and Health Canada, symptoms of COVID-19 may take up to 14 days to appear after exposure to the virus. There is only 2 months, 3 weeks and 3 days left until June 1, 2020. There would need to be 1,486 fatalities of COVID-19 to bring the number up to 5,501 fatalities. It appears that there is not "enough time" for the number of fatalities to increase beyond 5,500 given the actions that affected countries and the WHO have taken. However, depending on the events that follow, I may have to change my forecast. Sources: 
https://experience.arcgis.com/experience/685d0ace521648f8a5beeeee1b9125cd https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/about/symptoms.html https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/coronavirus-covid-19/ https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/symptoms.html

My forecast for total infected cases by 20 March is >200k.  With a 3.4% fatality rate, the number of deaths would be 6800, way above 5500, on 20 March, let alone 1 June.   Since the fatality rate of 3.4% is mainly derived from the cases in China, it may change over time as deaths outside China increase and outbreak in China tapers off.  Another way to look at the problem is to calculate the fatality rate needed to get to 5500 deaths, assuming a 200k infected cases.  It is 2.8%.  So far we have not seen this low a fatality rate outside China yet.  So there is a high probability for deaths >5500.

I am more optimistic than the crowd here that the figure won't exceed 5500. At 3.8% deaths/cases, that would require 145000 or fewer cases; at 3.5% (although 3.5% is unlikely), 157000. The figure may turn out to be around 6100. The logistic fit suggests that the "under control" date (which I define as being when there are no more than 1000 reported cases to come) may be around 31 March. There is unlikely to be a rapid growth of either cases or deaths in April and May.

Although I hope the death rate tapers off, people affected with pre-existing conditions, and the unknown number of people spreading the virus unconstrained will see this figure rise into mid May. Likely over 10,000 by then.

The cumulative number of deaths is now (2020-03-05) 3,282. The number of cases is 95,333. Worrying is the rise in cases in India. My forecast for the cumulative number of cases on June 1st (using a square sine-function to model the number of cases per day) is 247,600. The fraction (cumulative deaths)/(cumulative cases) for China is 3.74%. When we give this percentage a range between 2% and 4% the cumulative number of deaths on June 1st should be between 4,952 and 9,904 with a mean of 7,428. Rough estimates (uniform distribution and normal distribution) give probabilities between 12% and 6% that the number will be below 5,500. So my present estimate is 10% in the bracket 4,500-5,500 and 90% above 5,500.

Currently, most deaths are inside China, but China seems to have contained their outbreaks. ~500 deaths outside of mainland China currently, and we currently have 3300 deaths. These 500 deaths have mostly occurred w/in the last 2 weeks, or ~250 additional deaths per week. Assuming that we havent hit peak, I'd assumed another 250 deaths per week for the next month until non-China cases begin to recover, plus additional tail end deaths for both China and the US as the virus gets contained/managed. https://gisanddata.maps.arcgis.com/apps/opsdashboard/index.html#/bda7594740fd40299423467b48e9ecf6

Other strains may emerge after June 1, 2020. However, people will reduce their travel, improve their hygiene, telecommute and stay at home more. However, if new more virulent strains are produced as this disease spreads, then these forecasts will be low.

The big unknown is Africa where the number of reported cases is still very low. Still very steep rise  in number of death reported around the world.
There are about 90 days between now and June 1st. We are at 3,285 deaths and averaging about 75 a day. If we maintain this current rate, we will easily surpass 5,500.

The current death toll lags behind the total presently infected that will die, so popular existing mortality to case rates may not pay this sufficient attention. Hence the reported death rate of 2-3% being garbage, and the 6% figure of resolved cases is a better metric. The recovery rate is rising along with the new case total, but at 94% today from 58% in early Feb this looks to be at plateau given the 6% figure, which, I imagine will drop slightly as a higher percent of cases are reported in countries with better healthcare provision and treatment preparation than mainland China had. Only risks to it being under 5.5k are diagnosis and reporting issues due to clustering, 3rd world spread.

With the death toll already past 3,200 and us moving into a new phase of the disease, with a far more global spread, and with Iran spreading like wildfire, I'm confident we will see many more deaths so the "more than 5,500" is a reasonably optimistic case.

There are a few workings out to get to the outside view number: Death average - Since the virus started on 31 Dec (63 days ago),  there has been 3249 deaths. 3249/63 = 51.5 daily average. June 1 is 88 days away, 88 x 51.5 = 4532 + 3249 (current number) = 7781 WHO 3% prediction - The WHO today released stats saying the death rate is at 3%. Current infected is 95000. the 3 day average for infected is 2300 per day x 88 (days till June 1st) = 202,400. Whilst the average increase in cases over the past 3 days is  225,  x 88 = 19800.  
95000+202400+19800= 317,200. 3% = 9516 Death average increase - current deaths 3249. Last 3 days death average 45.66, x 88 = 4018.
Plus the average 3 day death increase, +4 x 88 = 352. 
3249+4018+352 = 7682  Averaging the 3 totals = 8326  Other factors to consider 
- Countries hiding the death toll - Iran are accused of not reporting deaths - Its difficult to say whether this is true or not. The chances are that if they continue to understate, they are likely to do so at the current rate, which is factored in the above calculations. If they report true figures, this will increase the calculations above. 
- Western countries are preparing for the virus and reports suggest that testing could enable people to find out earlier which could assist saving lives. 
- Minus Iran, the countries outside of China who are reporting high volumes of cases are wealthy countries, mostly in the G7, with better health services. It is likely that they may be able to administer better care than China and thus the rate will slow.  Considering these factors, i will reduce my calculation by 15%  = 7077.  One of the rare times i hope i am wrong. But i am as close to certain as i can be that the number will easy pass 5500.  Expect 7-8000 Sources - https://www.worldometers.info/coronavirus/coronavirus-death-toll/  Let me know what you think to my methods and conclusions. Feel free to critique.

Around 3,000 people have already died of COVID-19 as of March 2nd (https://www.who.int/docs/default-source/coronaviruse/situation-reports/20200302-sitrep-42-covid-19.pdf?sfvrsn=edd4f123_2). The mortality 3.42% of people who have been infected died of the virus. This mortality rate is higher than the expected 2%(https://www.livescience.com/coronavirus-updates.html).  COVID-19 seems to be more contagious than the common flu (https://www.nytimes.com/2020/02/29/health/coronavirus-flu.html) and in 2019, at least 18,000 people died (https://www.cdc.gov/flu/about/burden/preliminary-in-season-estimates.htm). Unless a magic wand was waved over the world. There is no way the death total will not rise by at least 3,000 people.

No time to do real research but it is wreaking havoc in Iran and has reached India and Brazil. All three countries not at all prepared to handle something like this IMO. India in particular, from my understanding, has a much higher level of close interpersonal contact --- e.g. it has ~6x the population of Brazil in ~1/3 of the area.

WHO is reporting 3043 deaths as of March 3 (https://www.who.int/docs/default-source/coronaviruse/situation-reports/20200302-sitrep-42-covid-19.pdf?sfvrsn=edd4f123_2) with 66 deaths in the last 24 hours. Assuming a fixed mortality rate: 60 deaths/day * 30 days/month * 3 months = 5400 new deaths which is well beyond 5500. In order for the total fatalities to be less than 5,500 there would have to be around 2450 or less deaths in the next three months which either means a vaccine needs to be discovered and rolled out completely in the next 40 days or the daily global mortality rate needs to drop off by a third (around 24 deaths per day as opposed to 66). I can't see any mechanism for the latter happening, and the chances of a vaccine being rolled out completely so that all infected are stopped seems extremely slim (especially considering that some countries are not coordinating such as North Korea).

Recent spread to many countries skews my model. Still, possibility of season ending and overall flattening of deaths (despite spiking of overall cases) lead me to think that doomsday scenarios may not happen. Will be updating on new data

Update:  As of March 2nd the WHO is reporting 41,151 active cases & the mortality rate has dropped to 6%.  So far 3069 people have died, and 6% of 41,151 = 2469.06, giving a total of 5538 within the current sample.  Meanwhile the number of cases outside China is accelerating with major outbreaks expected across Europe and confirmed numbers from Iran and the US just beginning their upward trajectory.   There remains some possibility of a medical breakthrough with chloroquine phos. or AIDS drugs, but further to reports that US citizens are being charged up to $300 for a test alone, workers are having to work while sick to survive & the NHS has next to no capacity for treating the majority of expected cases, I'm mindful that socio-economic & political circumstances don't lend themselves to swift containment or adequate care in the majority of countries now trying to suppress mushroom clouds of infection. Despite China, Vietnam & Singapore's best efforts, it seems likely that both the R0 & mortality rate for Covid19 will increase again once other nations' fragile public health systems are overwhelmed. Therefore shifting back up a little.

Assuming this has the same intervention-adjusted virulence as seasonal influenza, expect average 9% of population to get it over a year. At current death rate of 2.4% that translates to 16.6 million deaths/year. Majority of the spread will happen later, since it will follow an exponential growth pattern until it runs out of people to infect.  But this is still ~3 orders of magnitude below what it would do in 3 months at its peak under these assumptions, and under half an order of magnitude from where it already is. So technically no probability is 100 but when you can only do increments of 1%, 100 is more accurate  than 99.
Given all the news a correction is applied.

1. It is likely that the majority of cases are not detected. If this is the case, (a) the average mortality rate might turn out to be much lower than the currently estimated 2.3-2.5% but (b) the number of people who will catch the new virus will be much higher.
2. China is a developed country and much more regimented than most countries. Still, it spread rapidly and proved critical in about 4.5% of confirmed cases in the space of a month. It's unlikely that enough people will self-quarantine and follow religiously basic rules of hygiene in other countries, especially those where soap and clean water are not readily available. So, the virus will continue to spread and it's already affected over 50 countries around the world.
3. Some people who were infected, isolated, treated and given the all-clear have re-tested positive for the virus. This may be a statistical artefact or may have to do with flawed tests (e.g. false negatives, mistakes medical/lab staff may have made because of exhaustion), but it may also be a sign that either the virus is already mutating to a different (more/less lethal?) strain or that surviving the infection does not confer immunity for some other reason.

Quick theoretical math from this article quoting WHO: https://www.cnbc.com/2020/02/24/who-says-coronavirus-outbreak-in-china-has-peaked-new-cases-in-iran-and-italy-are-deeply-concerning.html  And the WHO situation report 39 released today Feb 28. Ok. So, 2-4% fatality rate within China, where the disease has already peaked and plateaued between Jan 23 and Feb 2. Current numbers of infected in China are 78,961 with 331 in the past 24 hours and 2791 deaths with 44 in the past 24 hours. Assuming high #s of casualties and assuming the daily communication rate holds steady, there are 93 days between now and June 1 so 93*331= 30,783 added to the current infected total = 109,744. 4% of that is 4389.76 so round up to 4390 added to the current death toll on China = 7181.  Let's see that on the conservative side with 2% casualty rate:  2194.88, rounded up and added =  4,986. NOW, for theory's sake I also want to simply multiply the rate of death from the past 24h and add it to the total to be certain. 44*93= 4,092. When you look at the daily numbers of people who died from CIVID-19 in China, you see a bell curve that can be approximated by a (modified) squared sine-function. Based on the known (daily) number of people who died OUTSIDE of China I optimised the parameters of the squared sine-function to fit these observations. Using these functions my forecast for June 1st are 3,375 for China and 3,200 for the rest of the world, giving a total fo 6,575 which is much higher than the upper limit 5,500.  Because the number of observations OUTSIDE China are still few the parameters of the squared sine-function have a lot of uncertainty. Therefore I give a 20% probability that the total will be in the range 4.5k to 5.5k.

As of 2/27 the WHO has reported 2804 deaths. Though the % daily growth in fatalities has fallen steadily, and currently sits at about 1.5%, we've still seen a roughly 39.5% increase in fatalities in 8 days since this question was posed. Using a relatively conservative fatality rate of 3% (current rate stands at 3.4% but has gone as low as 2.14%), 5500 fatalities requires 183,333 cases, a roughly 120% increase over the current figure. Seems highly unlikely the virus will have increased 40% in the last 8 days, yet fail to increase 120% in the next 95, especially given that there's little evidence cases have stopped growing in China (outside of Hubei), and it's just beginning to spread globally. Hoping to be wrong.

We are already at 2770 as of 26 Feb (see comprehensive time series of deaths by location at https://github.com/CSSEGISandData/COVID-19/blob/master/csse_covid_19_data/csse_covid_19_time_series/time_series_19-covid-Deaths.csv).
The numbers don't grow in a recognisable pattern. If you plot the daily change in the number of fatalities, you get a zigzag shape. But the number of people who die doesn't depend on how many people have died before, but on how many people are infected. According to the same dataset, visualised at https://public.tableau.com/profile/salvatore1114#!/vizhome/wdctest/COVID-19StatusUpdate, the mortality rate fluctuates between 2% and 3%. What it doesn't tell us is how long people were infected before they died. Also, most of the deaths so far have been in China. We don't know what the mortality rate will look like as the disease grows in other countries, which it is definitely doing. 
What we do know:
There are over 45,000 existing cases in China. If 2-3% of those succumb in the next 3 months which is the duration of the question, that makes 900 to 1350 fatalities. That already rules out the first two possible answers. There are about 3000 cases outside China, with big variations in mortality rates between countries. The numbers are pretty small in many countries meaning the rates are probably not reliable yet. South Korea has the most cases, with a 1% mortality rate that would add only about 12 people to the total. Iran has a rate of 14% but fewer cases so would only add about another 10.
If we assume current mortality rates will apply to currently infected people over the next 3 months (which is about as long as the disease has been running now to give us those rates), we get to between 3500 and 4500 deaths. If we allow that some of the new cases over the next 3 months may die, even if we don't know the rate, that means a possibility of over 4500 just because a lot more people are likely to be infected. There must be at least some possibility of over 5500 for the same reason. Hence my estimates, which are still incredibly crude and will doubtless need to be revised.

The veracity of the report also requires more testing & peer review.

As of the date of this forecast, it is clear that COVID19 is already a pandemic, although it hasn't officially been declared as such. This is an opinion, but I suspect very much that the WHO will confirm the pandemic within the next week. Why? As a fact, Japan, South Korea, Italy and, of course, China all have cases for which they have no idea of the transmission route/vector. It is therefore out of control/an epidemic, in my view. If that is the case, it is so on two continents (and likely a two more in NA and Afr). That's a pandemic. What other facts do we have? The disease appears to be as contagious as flu, but has at least 10 (and possibly 30 or 40) times the mortality rate. If it is out of control, and if as contagious as flu, but, for argument's sake, 20 times more lethal, we are going to be *way* over 5,000 by June. Why? About 8% of the US population catches flu each season. But that's as high as 11% in winter. Let's say that we only have two months of peak virus season left. Let's also say that the weather will be warmer than usual (as Accuweather predicts). Let's also say the novelty of this makes people more likely to self isolate totally or partially. Let's therefore imagine that in developed economies, covering, conservatively, 1 billion people, only 2% of people catch it, and of those, it's only fatal in flu proportions (which we know it won't be). That's still 20,000 deaths by June, just in the developed world -- i.e. 10 times more than we need to get from where we are now to over 5,500. For it to be less, we would have to start seeing evidence of containment within the next week or so, but the trend at the moment, outside China, is the opposite. Furthermore, China is taking steps to restart its economy, suggesting the possibility of a second wave in that country (possibly using Singapore style harm minimisation rather than containment methods).
Updating on new evidence. Current dynamics in outside-China numbers increases the tail risk. Current mean estimate shows ~36k by 01/06 with huge uncertainty.

Re-iterating my forecast with some more reasoning behind it.   If you take the number of deaths divided by the number of cases, you get 2,760/80,994=3.4%.  That would require 161,401 cases to get to 5,500 deaths.  That can certainly happen in about a month given the exponential growth of non-Chinese cases, provided that rate holds.  But, that is not an accurate estimate of mortality because of the delay between diagnosis and death, and the accelerating rate of new cases.  A better estimate of mortality would be deaths over (deaths + recoveries) 2,760/(30,000+2,760)=8.4%.  That would require 65,283 cases to get 5,500 deaths, less than the current total cases.  There are already enough infected people to reach the top bucket.
This is a global pandemic that will burn through the global population over the next few months.

As Covid-19 continues to spread, the virus, similar to other flu strains, has a higher rate of mortality in the elderly and those with multiple comorbidities. As the virus continues to spread in places like Europe, with dense population centers, generally older populations, and a more transparent record of reporting, I feel the number of fatalities will reach 5,500. On the other hand, I do not know yet how more westernized healthcare systems will cope, so fatality rates in this geography may be lower. On the other hand, I expect China to continue reporting at a fairly steady pace. There is also the chance of misreporting other strains as COVID-19, but that may be offset by the opposite occurring. Some data to consider:
On the 17.02.2020 the WHO wrote that "in 2% of reported cases, the virus is considered fatal, and the risk of death rises the older the infected person is". Today, 24/02/2020, without considering the new 50 deaths cases in Iran reported last night - that still has to be confirmed from the national and international authorities - the fatality rate is over 3%. No fatalities among the children between 0 - 9 years old. 
In a global society, a virus with this characteristic (similar to a common flu), could potentially spread everywhere becoming pandemic. Another variable to consider is the incubation period, that could be 14 days, which is considered a long period, or even more, scientists are still studying it. Moreover, there are people who were infected but without showing any symptoms. This could help the virus to expand the infection in incognito. Considerations & possible scenarios:
1) Almost 80000 cases in less than 2 months
2) More are the infected, and higher is the chance for the virus to replicate and spread across several people and different countries
3) Even Italy, a G20 country, and one of the best in terms of science and medical research, is now struggling to contain the infection, even if it seems that they used the right procedures to prevent and put in quarantine who was affected. What might happen then in the poorer countries that have usually more density in the population and less health care and prevention...?
4) If the virus will keep going to spread at the same pace of today , we should expect more less the triple of the cases of infected and deaths for June 2020.  Answers:
1) Today we have already more than 2500 cases of deaths, so the first possible answer must be 0%.
2) This scenario is unlikely to happen because the virus is spreading and the number of infected is rising. They should find a cure in the next days and apply it to all the infected around the world. Moreover, a system of perfect quarantine has to be applied in every country.
3) See above scenario 2).
4) If the infection and death rate will decrease, this scenario could be realistic even without a cure before June.
5) The most probable scenario following the current trend of the rise of the virus and given the data we can access today.

At this point all I can think to do is some very simple math with some huge assumptions which I will update as we progress towards the stated date of 1 June 2020. Rate of new infections appears to have slowed somewhat, averaging around 1,000 per day for the last 3 or 4 days.  Assuming this stays constant (a huge assumption), this would lead to around 96,000 new reported cases (96 days * 1,000 new cases per day). Assume that total CFR remains constant at 3.1%. Note that the current CFR of cases outside of China is approx. 0.1% while the CFR within China is around 3.2% (and Hubei's CFR is 3.7%) based on the 23 February 2020 WHO Situation Report.  My forecast assumes the rate of cases growth by region stays the same (ie more cases reported in China with a higher CFR, and less cases outside of China with a lower CFR) that the CFR of 3.1% remains relatively constant. 2,462 cases + 90,000 * 3.1% = 5,250 cases Now I will manually adjust this upwards given that there are many new cases in Italy and Iran which large unreported populations of the infected.  I think that if the early unveriffied reports that the large populations there the infected there becomes more reliable, the CFR will increase.  As such, I am putting my credences quite evenly between 4,500-5,500 and above 5,500. It should also be noted that total H1N1 deaths are predicted anywhere from 150,00-450,000.  How that is distributed over time in unclear.

There are currently 53,080 active cases, and 25,886 closed cases of which 2,468 (10%) resulted in death (https://www.worldometers.info/coronavirus/).  Even if there are literally zero new infections from today, we can expect perhaps 1 - 10% (estimates vary) of those currently active cases to end in death which is 2,998 - 7,776 total deaths.  But that's a best case, before we consider the continuing spread both in China (which appears to be slowing but has not stopped) and worldwide (new outbreaks have been discovered in several countries in the last few days) and the strong possibility that there are a lot of as-yet-undetected cases (perhaps milder on average than the currently recognized cases).
the peak has come, the weather is getting warmer, other countries are in doubt, treatment methods have already tried

Most cases remain in China and on the current figures and daily reduction in number of cases/deaths, it might be expected that the deaths might remain just under 5,500 by June 1st. Allowing for errors and deaths outside China, it seems highly likely for the number of deaths to be over 5,500 by that date. The question is when medical authorities will give up testing and directly attributing deaths to the virus. I don’t think that will happen before June as authorities seem very committed to controlling the spread.

Pessimistic forecast, but the more it spreads, the more it seems prone to spread. Latest numbers [1]:
-77,794 cumulative confirmed cases (1,025 new) and 2,359 cumulative confirmed deaths (112 new). Projections [2]:
-1) Projection based on average # new confirmed deaths of past two days shows that confirmed deaths will exceed: 2.5k on Feb. 24,  3.5k on March 3, 4.5k on on March 12, and 5.5k on March 21.
-2) Projection based on average day-on-day percent growth in confirmed deaths of past two days shows that confirmed deaths will exceed: 2.5k on Feb. 25,  3.5k on March 1, 4.5k on on March 6, and 5.5k on March 10. Overall, these simple linear projections should be taken with a grain of salt - epidemics, of course, do not scale linearly. But I take this approach because there is a lot of uncertainty at the moment, given that opposing forces are acting on the number of new confirmed deaths. Daily confirmed deaths are rapidly dropping off in China, but new clusters of cases are also rapidly appearing outside of China [3]. It is difficult to assess how these opposing trends counteract one another - hence, I have used a simple linear projection approach that assumes these two opposing trends will more-or-less cancel out.  In any case, the linear projection shows that the 5.5k death figure will be exceeded in March - and the timeline of this question extends for another two full months after that. Hence, I find it probable that 5.5k deaths will be exceeded. [1] Latest numbers: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1d0JKwNcQsGVEMSMiUg0dZshGg-fVjWb7un-CNOi-vXk/edit?usp=sharing
[2] Projections: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1RU4wiWov1YtjAhTOB_sq9uRBJIP6OmN6dsLOQrWEGd4/edit?usp=sharing
[3] https://www.statnews.com/2020/02/21/coronavirus-picking-up-steam-outside-china/

How many fatalities caused by the Wuhan coronavirus (COVID-19) will the World Health Organization (WHO) report as of 1 June 2020? Adjusting to better align with @piratecat.

Based on data from [1] it appears deaths are ascending pretty linearly right now. As of today there are 2360 deaths, so it is very clear that less than 2500 will not occur. In February, there have been around 80 new deaths a day. If we fully extrapolate from that, we would have an estimate of around 800*30 = 2400 per month which would give a final number well over 5500. However, given that the number of cases has been rising much slower recently than in early February and the shift to spring, it is likely we will end up much lower. I think less than 3500 would still be a very low estimate, but the later three categories all seem reasonable.  [1] https://www.worldometers.info/coronavirus/

Exponential growth even for only the non-Chinese cases (doubling every 6.2 days by my estimation) for the next 100 days or so blows these numbers out of the water.  That being said, things will probably taper off well before then. Even so, I find 5,500+ to be a pretty safe bet.

First approximation: there are already 2000+ deaths, currently with linear growth in China hopefully reaching saturation (saturation point somewhere between 3-5K). There is also exponential growth outside China, and I find it unlikely that there will be less than 100K by the date of the end of the question, giving 1-2K extra deaths. Yet it could be more (I wish to be wrong). Besides, a second peak in China is perfectly possible.

A contrarian view. Several factors. One is seasonality - so far other coronavirus infections have been seasonal. And season is ending. The 2nd factor - the data showing significant slowdown in overall deaths (as well as cases). From my logistic model, by June 1st, it is supposed to be 2.4-3.9K. The 3rd factor is expected improvements in care, hence, less fatality rate. Too early for vaccine, but cocktails of other antivirals...  Of course, it all depends upon that the preventive measures hold and outbreak is waning. Yup, I am an optimist and believe in sanity when humanity faces mortal challenges (except wars - there is different dynamic there). Will be watching for trends and updating regularly.

As of 21/02/20 10.84% of resolved cases have proved fatal.  With another 56,112 confirmed cases still unresolved, new outbreaks unfolding and serious lack of containment or preparation beyond China, global fatalities are almost certain to exceed 5,500 much sooner than June.
New global infections are tailing off while death rate in China is slowly creeping up beyond 2% of infections mostly of elderly male patients; 5% of the Chinese population is above 65 years old.

We'll most likely be over 2.5k deaths in china in a day or two. Assuming the Chinese have contained the outbreak and we stay in the 50-100 deaths per day range for a couple of months, we're still looking at something like 3k more deaths in China alone, putting us at > 5.5k. But let's say they really get a grip on this, it doesn't grow and they really reduce the number of cases. I'm going to guess that 1.5k more deaths in China is an irrationally optimistic scenario. (Recall there are over 11k serious cases currently, so that probably represents something like 500 deaths right there even with perfect containment going forward.) But in any case: if we just have 1.5k new deaths in China we would need just 1.5k deaths outside China by June 1 to get to 5.5k total. 1.5k deaths implies roughly 75k cases @ a 2-2.5% death rate The rest of the world should exceed that level of confirmed cases by early April if current growth rates continue.  Either way, I can't see this being under 5.5k unless something weird happens and the cases aren't reported. We could easily be much higher.

CFR currently ~2% so would need to infect >250,000 with little change in mortality to get over 5,500.  Treatment should be better now that more research has been done, and regions hopefully won't be as unprepared as Hubei so CFR should go down. *If* it's contained deaths should grow slower now. However I think there's a significant chance nCov won't be contained and will go global similar to swine flu, effectively an exceptionally bad flu, eventually killing 10s or even 100,000s. But not by July.
